Message.Title: This Week, March 17 2013
Message.Msg: This week, March 17 2013 Speaker of the House John Boehner was chief sound bite producer, stressing ideas such as that the president believes heaps more taxes from the American people are needed.Instead, he argues, we have a spending problem, not an income problem.You, the president, got your ill-advised tax hike January 1st of this year and have done nothing noticeable about any spending cuts. Boehner feels a debt crisis is not imminent, but is looming, and puts major blame upon what he calls “entitlement” growth, which he wishes to be placed on a “sustainable” course. Alternatively, perhaps the 'entitled' could start paying 'their fair share'. Today was hardly the first time he and other GOP stalwarts have said, “You cannot spend money you do not have.” Not that we aren't. Late, g f will, with usual harrumph, stated, “House and Senate are on path to pass budgets.Each budget will not be passed by the other house.” Carly Fiorina, making like politico rather than former CEO, hopes for fundamental tax reforms, attention to entitlements, and awareness that government does not spend all dollars wisely - hardly a novel idea. No wonder they axed her: prosaic don't get the job done!! She also wishes attention to “getting things done” rather than focusing upon GOP image. *sigh* CPAC’s gathering was mentioned, with the aforementioned Will noting rise of “libertarianism”, Matthew Dowdconsidering CPAC a past-century group whose time has seemed gone but is fast coming around again. President Obama is going to Israel to honk his horn and thumb his nose at Netanyahu some more; past Clinton NSC leader wants USA to take lead in “doing something” about Iran’s nuclear bomb ambitions. He, Stephen Hadley, considers “cyber attacks” a significant danger to the nation. Another novel idea. Although populace, by Washington Post poll, feels 3-2 that USA in Iraq and Afghanistan was unwise, Hadley feels we got “something” out of the operations.“Something” was government change in Iraq, attention to Al Qaida in Afghanistan. What a bunch of bat poop. What a PRICE. Bob Woodruff, ABC journalist injured in Iraq, called Iraq “far worse than imagined”, and hopes some of the necessary help of the injured military (now veterans) can be local in nature. Meaning what, having blown them up this government doesn't care to fix them? Nine members of USA military made ultimate sacrifice in Afghanistan—three from Florida.One in 30s, rest in 20s. Sponsors—mostly the usual ones; BP and banks, though, missing , if anyone gives a ratsass.

Message.Title: if you don't get it now, you never will
Message.Msg: Democracy Truth about Markets NYC – 03/15/13: Max and Stacy continue taking the banksters and financial terrorists to task in this entertaining installment. → Max Keiser on Cyprus: The debt bomb just got bigger Posted on March 18, 2013 by maxkeiser| 10 Comments The amount of debt worldwide is more than all of the bank accounts in the world, and the current financial situation in Cyprus is the inevitable next phase: Confiscation. All pretense is now gone that central or global bankers can ‘securitize’ growth by packaging and repackaging debt; by hypothicating and rehypothicating debt; by regulating and rergulating debt. Since the bond market rally began in the early 1980s (yes, it’s that old) each crisis has been met by central and global bankers – the IMF, EU and ECB, to name a few – and their Wall St. and City of London brethren with an increase in debt, and an extension of the debt’s maturity. The result has been – as of 2007 – the biggest mountain of on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet debt in history: A staggering $220 trillion in debt in America’s $14-trillion economy alone (when you include all public, private and contingent liabilities of unfunded entitlement programs). Deals in the global debt derivatives market now stand in excess of $1 quadrillion, riding above a global GDP of approximately $60 trillion. But starting in 2007, and then becoming spectacularly apparent in 2008 with the Lehman collapse, the ability of the world’s taxpayers to pay either the interest or principal on this debt has hit a brick wall. And for several years now, governments around the world have tried the same old tricks of ‘extend and pretend.’ Repackage and extend the maturity, and pray that tax receipts start picking up enough to pay some of the debt off. It didn’t work. The debt bomb just got bigger. Now in Cyprus we see the inevitable next phase: Confiscation. To pay off the debts that were incurred to finance the biggest wealth grab in history, we see in Cyprus, as well as central and global banking institutions around the world, a trend to just reach in and grab people’s money from their ‘insured’ bank accounts. We should have figured out this was coming when JP Morgan (read: Jamie Dimon) reached in and illegally stepped ahead of customers at MF Global and grabbed over $1 billion, with the help of his crony pal Jon Corzine. Have we learned our lesson yet? They have more debts to pay than there is money in all the bank accounts in the world. This means that chances are, you – whoever you are, and whatever country you live in – will have a sizable percent of your savings stolen by banksters. Since the crisis hit (and for several years leading up to it) we’ve been recommending on ‘Keiser Report’ to put as much money as you can in gold and silver. Our advice then and now is: The only money you should keep in a bank is money you’re willing to lose.

Message.Title: Debt-based currency a fraud on America
Message.Msg: The whole banking system in America is based on fraud; it is an elaborate scheme developed to enrich those that control the monetary system, at the expense of all others. Banks create money by giving out loans with money they don’t actually possess; and so we have money that is actually a debt certificate. This is all possible because we have a legal tender with no commodity backing — fiat currency — using a fractional reserve system. Bear with me. Banks regularly engage in fraud. They represent as if they’re storing your money in the bank, and you can have it back anytime you want. Anyone who has ever watched “It’s a Wonderful Life” should realize that the bank doesn’t actually have everyone’s deposits on reserve. Unfortunately, this Christmas classic leads us to believe that it’s OK to lend out money that has been deposited into a bank, even though that money is deposited with the understanding that you can withdraw it all on demand. A “run on the bank,” “credit crunch” or “frozen credit” is actually the result of the banks’ fraud being exposed. This is not a good reason to give bankers bailouts. The FDIC actually acts as a protection for this banking scheme because people are lulled into a false sense of security, and it takes longer for the fraud to be exposed. This whole financial system is powered by ignorance. Fortunately, if enough people uncover this scheme it will destroy debt-based currency.

Message.Title: Marketwatch: Meredith Whitney tells CNBC she has never been this bullish, BAC could DOUBLE
Message.Msg: March 18, 2013, 5:52 PM . Banking analyst Meredith Whitney Monday told CNBC’s “Closing Bell” she has “not been this constructive, this bullish on the U.S., on equities in my career.” Whitney said U.S. assets will likely benefit from the bailout in Cyprus, and added that investors “have to be bullish on U.S. equities here.” Her remarks come three months after she moved, correctly, to a bullish stance on financials, pointing out that there was more clarity in the sector than at any time over the past five years. She reiterated her upbeat stance on Bank of America BAC+0.96% and Discover DFS+1.36%, but also said the banking industry is likely to remain in the crosshairs of Congress, and that she wouldn’t be a buyer of JPMorgan JPM-0.22% stock, according to CNBC. She predicted that BofA could be close to double its current price by 2014 and that Discover has “all guns blazing.”
